==German== ===Alternative forms=== * {{l|de|diser}} {{qual|obsolete}} ===Etymology=== From {{etyl|gmh|de}} {{m|gmh|diser}}, {{m|gmh|disiu}}, {{m|gmh|diz}}, from {{etyl|goh|de}} {{m|goh|desēr}}, {{m|goh|disiu}}, {{m|goh|diz}}, from the {{etyl|goh|de}} demonstrative pronoun {{m|goh|der}}, from {{etyl|gem-pro|de}} {{m|gem-pro|*sa}}, from {{etyl|ine-pro|de}} {{m|ine-pro|*tód}}. Akin to Old Saxon {{m|osx|these}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{audio|de|De-dieser.ogg|Audio}} * {{IPA|de|/ˈdiːzər/}} * {{a|standard in most parts of German}} {{IPA|de|[ˈdiːzɐ]}} * {{a|standard in Switzerland, one of several standards in Bavaria and Austria}} {{IPA|de|[ˈd̥iːz̥ər]}} * {{IPA|de|/ˈdɪzɐ/}} {{a|colloquial; chiefly western Germany}} * {{hyphenation|de|die|ser}} ===Pronoun=== {{head|de|pronoun|cat2=demonstrative pronouns|demonstrative}} # [[this one]], [[this]] # [[that one]], [[that]] ====Usage notes==== * See {{l|de|dieses}} and {{l|de|dies}} for the use of these two variants of the nominative/accusative neuter. * Unlike English “this”, German ''dieser'' is not necessarily restricted to what is close to the speaker. The pronoun is indeed ''more likely'' to be used referring to something close, but it is by no means uncommon to say, for example: ''Siehst du diesen Turm da hinten am Horizont?'' Literally: “Do you see ''this'' tower back there at the horizon?” ====Declension==== {{de-decl-dieser}} ====Synonyms==== * {{l|de|der|g=m}}, {{l|de|die|g=f}}, {{l|de|das|g=n}} ====Derived terms==== * {{l|de|diesbezüglich}} * {{l|de|diesjährig}} * {{l|de|diesmal}} * {{l|de|diesseits}} * {{l|de|ebendieser}} * {{l|de|ohnedies}} * {{l|de|überdies}} ====Related terms==== * {{l|de|jener}} * {{l|de|derselbe}} ===Further reading=== * {{R:Duden}}
